<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 212, 616]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 918, 108]]<|/det|> 9 Strontium-90 ( \(^{90}_{38}\mathrm{Sr})\) is a radioactive isotope that contains 38 protons and 52 neutrons. Strontium-90 decays to form an isotope of yttrium (Y) by emitting beta ( \(\beta\) ) particles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 123, 144, 140]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 123, 175, 140]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 122, 918, 153]]<|/det|> (a) (i) Suggest how the nucleus of a stable isotope of strontium differs from a nucleus of strontium-90. Explain your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 170, 918, 186]]<|/det|> suggestion <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 201, 918, 216]]<|/det|> explanation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 278, 188, 295]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 277, 777, 294]]<|/det|> (ii) Complete the nuclide equation for the decay of strontium-90 to yttrium. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 316, 640, 350]]<|/det|> \[ \frac{90}{38} \mathrm{Sr} \longrightarrow \mathrm{Y} + \mathrm{\beta} \] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 373, 160, 390]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 371, 918, 388]]<|/det|> (iii) Explain why scientists limit the amount of time they are exposed to radioactive strontium. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 466, 144, 482]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 465, 875, 497]]<|/det|> (b) Yttrium is also unstable. A scientist places a sample of yttrium near a radiation detector.
